I think I saw this pattern in another PR and found it a bit weird, and now am reconsidering it again. Is it clearer to use throw newInvalidSchemeException(uri) so it's easy to see that this line is throwing an exception, without much change in verbosity (actually guess less characters / bytecode)?

nodes.diffHunk: @@ -69,12 +68,12 @@ default void serviceAdded(ServiceConfig cfg) throws Exception {} * } * * @param type the type of the object to return - * @return the object of the specified {@code type} if found. {@link Optional#empty()} if not found. + * @return the object of the specified {@code type} if found. {@code null} if not found.

nodes.bodyText: Feels a bit odd to have two Return / @return in a single javadoc.
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -171,11 +170,12 @@ public String defaultHostname() {
      * Returns the primary {@link ServerPort} that this {@link Server} is listening to. This method is useful
      * when a {@link Server} listens to only one {@link ServerPort}.
      *
-     * @return {@link Optional#empty()} if this {@link Server} did not start
+     * @return {@code null} if this {@link Server} did not start

nodes.bodyText: Seems to me that the Javadoc body gets too long if I move what's written in @return..
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -171,11 +170,12 @@ public String defaultHostname() {
      * Returns the primary {@link ServerPort} that this {@link Server} is listening to. This method is useful

nodes.bodyText: Here especially, I'd expect just , or {@code null}... inlined with the first line.
I think IntelliJ refactor might have un-static imported the assertions. Though is migrating to junit5 also the time to migrate to assertj? ;)
Let's make this consistent. or {@code null} otherwise.
